Colin Green wrote:

>This large 
>negative loopback weight would also have the effect of reducing all 
>output to 0.0 if I relaxed the network based upon waiting for a stable 
>ouput value (I read the FAQ entry thanks Ken).
>  
>
I just tested if the output would relax to 0.0, here are the results in 
an extended version of the previous truth table:

0    1    2    3(t1)    3(t2)    3(relaxed)
------------------------------------------
1    0    0    0.83     0.01      (oscillates between 0.01 and 0.82)
1    0    1    0.16     0.05      0.089
1    1    0    0.16     0.05      0.089
1    1    1    0.007    0.007     0.0066


Seems I was wrong then.

The oscillator presents a problem though when using the relaxation 
technique of waiting for output values to stabilize. Ken, in your XOR 
code you seem to be calculating a depth value for a network, you then 
execute 'depth' number of timesteps to allow input signals chance to 
propagate to the output nodes, right? This solves the oscillation 
problem, but the depth calculation sounds potentially CPU intensive - 
it's essentially the same algorithm that is required for determining 
node layers which we were discussing on the list just recently. I'll 
look into how you're detecting recurrency and have a think about this, I 
think it's going to be a case of defining 2 or 3 relaxation techniques 
and picking the one best suited for a given domain. Right now my domains 
(all 2 of them) use a fixed number of timesteps that I guess at based 
upon how big a network is required to solve the task...which partly 
defeats the purpose of neat!

Colin
